data.body: A capacitor is a system comprising two conductors with charges \( Q \) and \(-Q\). To determine the energy stored in this setup, let's consider two initially uncharged conductors, 1 and 2. Imagine a process of transferring charge from conductor 2 to conductor 1 bit by bit, resulting in conductor 1 obtaining a charge \( Q \) and conductor 2 having a charge \(-Q\) at the end.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: During the transfer of positive charge from conductor 2 to conductor 1, external work is done since conductor 1 is at a higher potential than conductor 2. To calculate the total work done, we start by calculating the work done in transferring an infinitesimal amount of charge.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Consider the intermediate situation where conductors 1 and 2 have charges \( Q' \) and \(-Q' \) respectively. At this stage, the potential difference \( V' \) between conductors 1 and 2 is \( \frac{Q'}{C} \), where \( C \) is the capacitance of the system.

data.name: paragraph

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Since the electrostatic force is conservative, this work is stored in the form of potential energy of the system. The final result for potential energy (\( W \)) is independent of the manner in which the charge configuration of the capacitor is built up.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: When the capacitor discharges, this stored-up energy is released. The potential energy of the capacitor can be viewed as 'stored' in the electric field between the plates.
